awd_titl_txt: Establishing a generalizable model for predictable antisense RNA repression
awd_abstract_narration:
RNA is mostly known as a messenger to convey genetic information, while small RNA plays important roles in gene regulation. Such regulatory RNAs have been found to exist naturally in many organisms, but they have been used in a relatively limited number of bacteria as a tool to regulate gene expression. In this project, the investigators will develop generalizable RNA regulators that can be used to understand and engineer diverse biotechnologically important bacteria. Specifically, design principles for antisense RNA (asRNA), one of the common regulatory RNAs in bacteria, will be determined to provide biologists and bioengineers with predictable RNA tools for gene regulation. Additionally, this project is broadly impactful by cultivating the next generation. Multiple graduate students will be trained to perform the interdisciplinary project. Moreover, our outreach program will introduce state-of-the-art synthetic biology RNA tools to high school teachers, and provide them with teaching kits that will be used in their classroom, broadening student participation in science and engineering.

The long-term goal of this project is to determine quantitative design principles for asRNAs and provide a generalizable model that enables predictably tunable asRNA-mediated gene repression in diverse organisms. asRNA is one of several types of small regulatory RNAs, and it represses gene expression by binding to its target messenger RNA. Although this binding occurs following the simple RNA base-pairing rule, predictably tunable asRNA-mediated repression is still challenging. The most important design parameters for asRNA in Escherichia coli DH10B have been identified by using three target reporter genes in plasmids. A predictive model for asRNA-mediated repression, which relates repression efficiency to the identified parameters by a multiple linear regression analysis, will be developed. To demonstrate the generalizability of this model, three specific aims are proposed. First, the model developed with plasmid reporters in E. coli DH10B will be validated by expanding it to chromosomal gene targets. This task will allow for testing of forward-designed asRNAs in different genetic contexts. Second, the predictive model will be tested in three different bacterial species. This task will test the hypothesis that asRNA design principles are consistent among diverse bacteria. Third, the model will be further validated by building and testing additional asRNAs. A user-friendly online version of the model will also be developed to provide a way to collaboratively advance this RNA-based technology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
This work provides a substantial contribution to the field of synthetic biology by developing a data-driven multivariate model that can accurately predict antisense RNA (asRNA)-mediated repression efficiency in bacteria. Importantly, this study provides a strategy that can be adopted to create new data-driven mathematical models for RNA regulator design in diverse organisms.

 

The study of synthetic asRNA has been one of the most exciting areas of research in synthetic biology. The combination of scientific and engineering approaches has transformed how we utilize asRNAs to program biological networks and systems. However, accurately predicting tunable repression via asRNA is still challenging, despite the simple complementarity rule between asRNA and mRNA. To address this issue, we created a predictive model using two predictors, change in free energy of complex formation (ΔGCF) and percent mismatch. Using our model (i.e., small-scale machine learning), we accurately predicted asRNA-mediated repression of target genes in both plasmids and chromosomes, and simultaneously modulated toxin and its antitoxin expressions to demonstrate tunable control of cell density. Furthermore, we showed that the predictive model developed in E. coli DH10B is valid for E. coli Nissle 1917 (probiotic strain) and B. subtilis 168 (Gram-positive strain). We envision that our model will be broadly applicable to enable forward-engineering. 

 

We started many activities as well. First, the PI has been organizing and chairing the Synthetic Biology Young Speaker Series (SynBYSS; https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTkyl4Uw1NlpuLCeP4Zi8aA) in which a global thought leader gives an opening 5 min talk, followed by a 45 min, rising star?s talk, for >1,000 global audiences from US, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, European Countries, Australia, Korea, China, Taiwan, Japan, Singapore, Indonesia, India, Africa, etc. Considering the gender balance, the PI made the seminar schedule such that the speaker list for the first four weeks consists of 7 female and 6 male researchers, including Prof. Frances Arnold (Nobel Laureate and co-chair of President Joe Biden's PCAST), Dr. Theresa Good (NSF BIO MCB Director), Prof. Beverly Wendland (WashU provost), Dr. India Hook-Barnard (EBRC Executive Director), Caitlin Deane (Nature Chemical Biology Editor), Chelsea Hu (Postdoc at Caltech), and Theresa Loveless (Postdoc at UC-Irvine).

 

Second, the PI has been actively engaging in various activities to have broader impacts. For example, as a council member of EBRC (https://ebrc.org/), the PI championed DEI by giving feedback on this topic through interviews and discussion. Additionally, among >40 presentations that the PI has given in 2021, many talks are for the global, inclusive synthetic biology community, including Global Open Genetic Engineering Competition (GOGEC; https://www.gogecconference.org/), SynBio Africa (https://synbioafrica.com/), BIOS2021 (http://synbio.id/), the Free 2nd International BioDesign Research Conference (https://www.biodesign-conference.com/2021/). In particular, the PI's support for GOGEC originated from his discussion with its founders early spring in 2021, regarding affordable or free participation in a global synthetic biology competition event. The prohibitive fees for the iGEM registration ($5,500) and jamboree ($2,500) prevented many teams in developing countries from attending it in 2021 due to the lack of financial supports from companies and universities affected by COVID (https://igem.org/Main_Page). Our voice made iGEM create many grant opportunities for which the PI also began to serve as a grant review committee member.

 

Together with other supports from 6 more funders, the Moon lab has contributed to the global synthetic biology community with 10 papers/book chapters published or under review related to this project and the global outreach activities. Thus, this project is successful by making technological advance, gaining fundamental understanding of small RNA regulation, and broadening STEM education globally.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Tae Seok Moon
